definition: Open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning; unclear or inexact.
mnemonic: Ambiguous sounds like 'ambi-gues,' as in something that can be guessed in multiple ways because it’s unclear.
visual_representation: Picture a road sign with arrows pointing in different directions, symbolizing ambiguity.
example_sentence: The instructions were so ambiguous that nobody knew what to do next.

mnemonic: Burly sounds like 'bull-y,' as in someone as strong and heavy as a bull.
visual_representation: Picture a big, muscular man lifting heavy weights, symbolizing someone burly.
example_sentence: The burly security guard easily restrained the intruder.

definition: To arrange (laws or rules) into a systematic code; to organize and make something systematic.
mnemonic: Codify sounds like 'code-ify,' as in turning rules into a systematic code.
visual_representation: Picture a stack of legal documents being organized into a neat, systematic code, symbolizing codification.
example_sentence: The government plans to codify the new regulations into law.

definition: To pour out or throw out (something, especially food or liquid) from the mouth or throat; to discharge forcefully.
mnemonic: Disgorge sounds like 'dis-gorge,' as in a gorge or throat forcibly throwing something out.
visual_representation: Picture a volcano violently erupting and spewing out lava, symbolizing disgorging.
example_sentence: The river disgorged its contents into the ocean after the heavy rains.

definition: To make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
mnemonic: Exacerbate sounds like 'ex-acer-bate,' as in making a situation more acute or severe.
visual_representation: Picture someone pouring fuel on a small fire, causing it to flare up and worsen, symbolizing exacerbation.
example_sentence: His harsh words only served to exacerbate the tension in the room.

definition: The face of a building, especially the front that looks onto a street or open space; an outward appearance that is maintained to conceal a less pleasant or creditable reality.
mnemonic: Facade sounds like 'face-ade,' as in the front face of a building or a false front to hide the reality.
visual_representation: Picture a beautiful building front with cracks behind the surface, symbolizing a facade.
example_sentence: Despite her calm facade, she was actually quite nervous.

definition: Involving or showing violence and bloodshed.
mnemonic: Gory sounds like 'gore-y,' as in filled with blood and violence.
visual_representation: Picture a battlefield scene with graphic violence, symbolizing something gory.
example_sentence: The horror movie was so gory that many viewers had to look away.

definition: Having or showing no skill; clumsy.
mnemonic: Inept sounds like 'in-apt,' as in not apt or lacking skill.
visual_representation: Picture someone trying to juggle but dropping all the balls, symbolizing ineptness.
example_sentence: His inept handling of the situation only made things worse.

definition: Crude and offensive in a sexual way.
mnemonic: Lewd sounds like 'lewd-ness,' indicating crude or inappropriate sexual behavior.
visual_representation: Picture someone making inappropriate gestures or comments, symbolizing lewdness.
example_sentence: The comedian's lewd jokes were not appreciated by the audience.

mnemonic: Muggy sounds like 'mug-gy,' as in the air is thick like being in a mug, warm and sticky.
visual_representation: Picture a hot, sticky day with heavy, humid air, symbolizing muggy weather.
example_sentence: The weather was so muggy that everyone was drenched in sweat.

definition: To destroy utterly; to wipe out.
mnemonic: Obliterate sounds like 'ob-liter-ate,' as in making something liter-ally disappear or be destroyed.
visual_representation: Picture a building being demolished into dust, symbolizing obliteration.
example_sentence: The powerful storm obliterated the small coastal town.

definition: (Of an argument or statement) seeming reasonable or probable.
mnemonic: Plausible sounds like 'plausi-ble,' as in something that can be applauded for being believable or likely.
visual_representation: Picture a detective considering a suspect’s story as making sense, symbolizing plausibility.
example_sentence: The explanation seemed plausible, so the detective decided to investigate further.

definition: A measure or condition that keeps someone or something under control; self-control.
mnemonic: Restraint sounds like 're-strain,' as in holding back or controlling something.
visual_representation: Picture someone holding back a powerful horse with reins, symbolizing restraint.
example_sentence: He showed great restraint by not responding to the provocations.

definition: (Adjective) Having assets in excess of liabilities; able to pay one's debts. (Noun) A substance that dissolves a solute, resulting in a solution.
mnemonic: Solvent sounds like 'solve-vent,' as in having the means to solve financial problems or dissolve substances.
visual_representation: Picture someone paying off debts with ease, symbolizing financial solvency, or a liquid dissolving a substance.
example_sentence: The company managed to stay solvent despite the economic downturn.

definition: (Of cloth) becoming thin and tattered with age; (Of an argument, excuse, idea, etc.) used so often that it is no longer effective.
mnemonic: Threadbare sounds like 'thread-bare,' as in cloth that is so worn out it’s almost bare of threads.
visual_representation: Picture an old, worn-out carpet with patches showing through, symbolizing threadbare.
example_sentence: The threadbare sofa was a testament to how long it had been in the family.

definition: A place or position affording a good view of something; an advantage in a contest.
mnemonic: Vantage sounds like 'advantage,' indicating a position that gives an advantageous view or perspective.
visual_representation: Picture someone standing on a hill with a clear view of the landscape, symbolizing a vantage point.
example_sentence: From their vantage on the hill, they could see the entire battlefield.
